medium_description_en: Determines likelihood of pediatric patients developing childhood asthma.
instructions_en: This score applies to pediatric patients ≤3 years old.

seo.meta_description_en: The Asthma Predictive Index (API) determines likelihood of pediatric patients developing childhood asthma.
seo.keywords_en: Asthma, predictive, index, childhood asthma, asthma diagnosis, pediatric asthma, stringent asthma index, loose asthma index

how_to_use.use_case_en: Children/infants 3 years or younger with wheezing episodes.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Asthma Predictive Index (API) provides a method for predicting likelihood of a later diagnosis of asthma, similar to the Modified Asthma Predictive Index (mAPI).
  • The API is only relevant in young children with wheezing.
  • While specificity is good, the score is not a good screening tool — it does not detect many patients who will later be diagnosed with asthma.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Clinicians may be more aggressive with trials of asthma medications in patients who are likely to be diagnosed with asthma later in life.

next_steps.advice_en: Consider that bronchodilators or steroids may be helpful in patients with respiratory illnesses, especially if they meet strict criteria for future asthma diagnoses.

about.formula_en:
Strict Criteria:

  • ≥3 episodes of wheezing per year, AND
  • ≥1 major criteria OR ≥2 minor criteria

Loose Criteria:

  • <3 episodes of wheezing per year, AND
  • ≥1 major criteria OR ≥2 minor criteria
about.more_info_en:
In the derivation study:

  • 59% of children with a positive loose index had active asthma at school age (defined at 15 years).
  • 76% of those with a positive strict index had active asthma at school age (defined at 15 years).

Original/Primary Reference.text: Castro-Rodríguez JA, et al. A clinical index to define risk of asthma in young children with recurrent wheezing. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2000; 162: 1403–1406.

Other References.text: Leonardi NA, et al. Validation of the Asthma Predictive Index and comparison with simpler clinical prediction rules. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2011 Jun;127(6):1466-72.e6.

creator_info.about_en: José Castro-Rodríguez, MD, is a profesor of pediatrics in the Department of Pediatric Pulmonology at Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine in Santiago, Chile. He was awarded the Master of Latin American Pediatric Pulmonology from the Latin American Pediatric Pulmonolgy Society in 2018. Dr. Castro-Rodríguez's primary research is focused on respiratory diseases, such as asthma, bronchitis, and tuberculosis, in pediatric patients.
